messages.subject: Re: tsuba kanji
messages.msgSnippet: all, as we all know kanji literally means   words of Han  , it would make more sense if you study Chinese too.  Sometimes they interchange with the
messages.messageBody:
all,
as we all know kanji literally means " words of Han ", it would make
more sense if you study Chinese too. Sometimes they interchange with
the pronounciation just to confound the gaijins............

just my opinion, of course.

milt

messages.subject: Re: [nihontostudy] tsuba kanji
messages.msgSnippet: I ll tell you, Jim, this translating Japanese texts is difficult.  I ve got four dictionaries here, and I still can t find some of the kanji I need, or even a
messages.messageBody:
I'll tell you, Jim, this translating Japanese texts is difficult. I've got four dictionaries here, and I still can't find some of the kanji I need, or even a sensible definition of some gana (!), to do two lines of a tsuba description. I'll be crawling back with questions later today, after I finish bombing out.

Spahn/Hadamitzky is a big improvement on Nelson, but it too is not sufficiently complete.
----- Original Message -----
From: Jim Gilbert
To: nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com
Sent: Sunday, August 14, 2005 11:38 AM
Subject: Re: [nihontostudy] tsuba kanji


Yes.



But you're supposed to read them both as "tsuba" in our usual context?



鐔 can be also be read tan or shin

鍔 can also be read as gaku.



[Non-text portions of this message have been removed]
